course.subject: CIVL
course.name: Environmental Impact Assessment
course.description: This course describes relationship of environmental impact assessment (EIA) and environmental policy act; methods and procedures for environmental impact identification, prediction, evaluation and mitigation; contents in an EIA report.
course.prerequisites: CIVL 1140 or CIVL 2410

reviews.author: Watermelonsuga
reviews.title: The course content is useful
reviews.comment_content: You will learn everything about EIA study, including but not limited to air, noise, water, biological impacts and visual impacts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Well, lots of people say his teaching is boring but how fun could that even be... I enjoyed his class as he's a super kind professor, and he's already tried his best to make the course interactive.
reviews.comment_grading: IDK I just finished the exam so I am trying to see how others were graded haha. The final exam is open book but only a hard copy can be used, try not to print out everything as I do... You definitely need to study a week before so you can get those calculations right. Ahh the questions on BOD is super difficult, didn't actually expect he will ask us questions about that...
reviews.comment_workload: SUPER simple homework, you can finish each of them within 1hour or even less. Throughout the term we only had 3 homework, no presentation no group project no quiz. yeah.

reviews.author: Guesswhat
reviews.title: pretty good
reviews.comment_content:
Everything about EIA
EIA in HK, Mainland, US
More or less the same but some differences

• Week 1: EIA and national/regional environmental policy act;
• Week 2: Planning and management of EIA;
• Week 3: Methods for impact identification; Description of environmental setting;
• Week 4-6: Prediction and assessment of air impact;
• Week 7-8: Prediction and assessment of water impact;
• Week 9: Prediction and assessment of noise impact; midterm exam;
• Week 10: Prediction and assessment of biological impact;
• Week 11: Prediction and assessment of visual impact;
• Week12-13: Environmental monitoring; Preparation of EIA Reports according to the EIA Ordinance by the Hong Kong EPD; Case studies of EIA for several types of civil engineering projects;
• Week14-15: Help session and final exam.

reviews.author: SQ Flyer
reviews.title: Very boring content but definitely recommended brush grade course
reviews.comment_content:
CIVL 4430 EIA is an elective course for CIVL/CIEV/EVMT students. Students should have completed CIVL 1140/2410 before joining this course. I would say the content is comparatively easy for a 4000-level elective course and CIVL students with prior knowledge would find the EIA content & calculations are much easier than those covered in CIVL 2410.

I would say the content covered both quantitative and qualitative methodologies in assessing various types of environmental impacts of a proposed project during the design, construction & operation stages. However, the content are somehow outdated or simplified compared to today's industrial practice.
(Prof managed to reuse the notes for decades)

Outline:
1. EIA & national/regional environmental policy act in HK/China/US
2. Planning & management of EIA
3. Methods for impact identifications, description of environmental setting
4. Air impact
5. Water impact
6. Noise impact
7. Biological & ecological impact
8. Visual impact
9. EM&A, EIA Report preparation, EIAO

The total number of slides is around 250 pages for the entire course, so it is easy to manage given some of the content are just common sense or you just learnt them before.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I see Xiang-ru try his best to make the lecture interactive by randomly asking questions, but I think most find his teaching boring given that the content are comparatively easy and this is a 9 am lecture.

Also, he speaks too slow with some extraordinary accent (like pronouncing students name in Mandarin way which is very disgrace), and you will find him lagging behind the schedule for weeks, even he still managed to finish all the stuffs on time. But still the delivery is very clear and he encourages students to type questions in the chat box. He will reply all those questions after class through mass email.

You will also find Xiang-ru has no sense of humor. In the middle of the class, he will suddenly play a random, unrelated video to serve as an attention seeker, but he fails to do so by looking all the boring faces from students. Yes, you are one-hundred percent boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
This year due to COVID again, no midterm.

Attendance: 5%
Assignments * 4 15%
Final 80%

Final is just a comprehensive assessment for the whole course. If you manage to do well by copying all the remarks on the notes and read them all in detail around 1-2 weeks before the exam, then you will excel in this course. The exam lasts for 1.5 hours  with 10 conceptual questions and 3 calculation questions which are very similar to assignment problems.  

My grade:
Attendance: full
Assignment: full
Final: unknown (I think I managed to get >80% of the total score even I don't know how to find minimum DO and made a careless mistake...)

Turns out A+.

So I really recommend you to join this class as an elective.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light for this course. So I really recommend you to take this if you just look up for a nice grade.

4 assignments where you will find yourself relax if you have sources from your seniors. Even you don't have, the calculation questions are easy by simply following the lecture notes. Every single assignment would just spend you less than an hour to complete. They provide an entire week for you to do so, so it is very manageable.

However, students should come to real-time lecture not only because attendance counts, you need to make extra remarks on the lecture notes in every single class, the professor includes more annotations and explanations on specific terminologies, you better write all down since those remarks are examined too.

You should note that this year the professor didn't provide any lecture videos due to copyrights issue. You better attend the real-time lecture or else you are fucked.

If you have a senior who shared his previous notes to you, you will find all the annotations are way the same :)

reviews.author: Cookies
reviews.title: Good grade but cannot learn much
reviews.comment_content:
Apart from the above description, the course also compares the environmental policies of USA, HK and China; prediction and assessment of air/water/noise/biological/visual impact. Most of the course content are calculations so students from civil might find it quite easy to handle but student from ENVS/EVMT might find it difficult.
As this course focuses on calculation, the contents are rather superficial or not comprehensive enough.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof likes to ask student questions so as to take attendance. Lots of note are came from what he wrote in class. It is advised to attend all lesson if possible as both midterm and final exams are allowed to bring your notes (open-notes exam), so the notes are IMPORTANT.
reviews.comment_grading:
Mark allocation: Attendance 5%, Homework 15%, Midterm exam 40%, Final exam 40%
Average grade would be B+ to B. Professor did not state the grading system is absolute grading or curving but he was so generous to give out really good grades. Around one-third of students obtained A range, almost half obtained B range and the rest are C+ and C.
Grade distribution was as follows (officially released from Prof.) [Grade(#stud)] : A+(9), A(13), A-(20), B+(24), B(23), B-(9), C+(17), C(9), Audit(1). Total number of students:125.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 assignments and 1 "project" (individual)
Compared with other civil courses, this course has a lighter workload. Most of the questions in the assignments are just simple calculations. The project you can view as a bigger assignment. They are also calculations and all you need to do is to well define the initial situation.
All assignments and the project are same as the previous years. You can definitely have those sources and copy but they are easy enough to do them by yourselves.
